free_text.Learning outcomes: Demanding applications require the processing power and/or[br/]I/O throughput offered by multiple CPU's, organized as[br/]multi-cores and/or as PC clusters. The course will introduce[br/]methods for the parallelization of applications on PC clusters.[br/][br/]
free_text.Content: - parallel architectures,[br/]- parallelization methods,[br/]- multi-threaded parallel programming[br/]- parallelization metrics,[br/]- theoretical performance models,[br/]- parallel program development,[br/]- debugging techniques and[br/]- measurement of program execution times[br/]- flow control & load balancing[br/]Environments:[br/]- Visual C++ under Windows or Linux[br/]- DPS C++ library for creating flow graphs defining parallel[br/]execution schedules.[br/]- OpenMP, MPI[br/]Project: Select a problem, predict the speedup, develop the[br/]parallel program (1 to 8 PC's) and compare predicted and[br/]measured performances.[br/]Proposed projects: sorting algorithms, knight tour,[br/]checkerboard path finding, synthesis of prime numbers,[br/]resource allocation, vector quantization, Matrix[br/]multiplication, FFT, linear equation systems (Jacobi[br/]iterations, Gaussian elimination), N-Body simulation, Hough[br/]transform, LU factorization, synthesis of color lookup table,[br/]image skeletonization, fish-eye transformation, boundary[br/]detection, distance transform, image filtering, interaction[br/]between light an prints (Monte-Carlo simulation) .
free_text.Form of examination: Continuous control (mini-project, rounding of grade[br/]according to laboratory reports)
free_text.Bibliography and material: Cours polycopié: Program Parallelization, vente des cours[br/]B. Wilkinson, M. Allen, Parallel Programming, Prentice Hall, 1999[br/]T. Bräunl, Parallel  Image Processing, Springer, 2001[br/]
